t: Song of Solomon 6
Others
Where*pn has your beloved gone, O*ld most beautiful among women? Where*ln has your beloved turned, that*ld we may seek him with you?
Together in the Garden of Love
She
My*pn beloved has gone down to his garden to*ld the beds of spices, to*ln graze in the gardens and*ld to gather lilies.
I*ln am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine; he*ld grazes among the lilies.
Solomon and His Bride Delight in Each Other
He
You*pn are beautiful as Tirzah, my love, lovely*ld as Jerusalem, awesome*ld as an army with banners.
Turn*ln away your eyes from me, for*ld they overwhelm me— Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats leaping*ld down the slopes of Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of ewes that*ld have come up from the washing; all*ln of them bear twins; not*ld one among them has lost its young.
Your*ln cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate behind*ld your veil.
There*ln are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and*ld virgins without number.

My*ln dove, my perfect one, is the only one, the*ld only one of her mother, pure*ld to her who bore her. The*ln young women saw her and called her blessed; the*ld queens and concubines also, and they praised her.
“Who*pn is this who looks down like the dawn, beautiful*ld as the moon, bright as the sun, awesome*ld as an army with banners?”
She
I*pn went down to the nut orchard to*ld look at the blossoms of the valley, to*ln see whether the vines had budded, whether*ld the pomegranates were in bloom.
Before*ln I was aware, my desire set me among*ld the chariots of my kinsman, a prince.
Others
Return,*pn return, O Shulammite, return,*ld return, that we may look upon you.
He
Why*pn should you look upon the Shulammite, as*ld upon a dance before two armies?
